etymologies: late 18th century: from Latin efflorescere, from e- (variant of ex-) ‘out’ + florescere ‘begin to bloom’ (from florere ‘to bloom’, from flos, flor- ‘flower’)

definitions: (of a substance) lose moisture and turn to a fine powder on exposure to air.
shortDefinitions: (of substance) lose moisture and turn to fine powder on exposure

definitions: (of salts) come to the surface of brickwork, rock, or other material and crystallize there.
shortDefinitions: come to surface of brickwork, rock, or other material and crystallize there

definitions: (of a surface) become covered with salt particles.
reach an optimum stage of development; blossom

examples.text: simple concepts that effloresce into testable conclusions
